description:
Melopsittacus undulatus, commonly known as the budgerigар or parakeet, is a small parrot species native to Australia. It is a member of the family Psittaculidae, which includes a wide variety of parrots and parakeets.

Melopsittacus undulatus is a small bird, typically measuring around 18 cm (7 inches) in length. It has a distinctive appearance, with a small, rounded head, a short, curved beak, and a slender, elongated body. The plumage of the budgerigар is typically green, with a distinctive pattern of black and yellow wavy lines (undulations) across the body and wings.

These birds are highly social, living in large flocks in the wild. They are known for their ability to mimic human speech and other sounds, making them a popular choice as companion birds. Budgerigars are omnivorous, feeding on a variety of seeds, grains, fruits, and insects.

Melopsittacus undulatus is one of the most widely kept and bred parrot species in the world, with numerous color mutations and varieties developed through selective breeding. They are considered a popular and relatively low-maintenance pet bird, known for their active, playful, and inquisitive nature.
